> Vera Peeters writes:
> > Implement the important things in normal java classes. You
> > can test those easily with JUnit.
> > The EJB should be only a very THIN facade into this java
> > package. The EJB doesn't do anything by itself, it only
> > redirects the client requests.
>
> This is a nice aim, but it's not always possible. That said, it's still
worth striving for.
> The main problem area is when you want your EJB to leverage the container
in some way. For example, you might want to lookup another > EJB.


My functional code does need information from other EJBs, that's true. But I
still try to follow the rule that the functional code is not allowed to
access the EJB layer. The thin EJB however that sits on top of the
functional code lives in the EJB layer, and he IS allowed to access other
EJBs. So I let the EJB talk to other EJBs, collect all necessary information
that my functional layer needs, and let it pass that information in.

So far, it has always been possible.

Now we have some vertical slices in the code that are entirely independent
of each other. There's an interface layer on top of each, and that interface
happens to be implemented by EJBs. The EJBs act as glue code between the
different vertical slices.
